dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stock footage of late 50's - early 60’s Manhattan - night time shots of vintage skyscrapers, traffic, and people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vinyl upholstery and mirrored walls, but brand new. It's after work, but the women have their hair done and each m tie is pushed to the top of his collar. Highballs and martinis clink under quiet music and everywhere are the sights and sounds of smoking. Alone in a red corner booth is DON DRAPER, early 30's, handsome, conservative, and despite his third old fashion he is apparently sober. He is doodling on a cocktail napk He crosses something out, puts down his fountain pen, and taps a cigarette out of a pack of "Lucky Strike". The BUSBOY, a middle-aged black man, too old for his tigh uniform, approaches.

dialogues.speaker: BUSBOY
dialogues.text: Finished, sir?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Yeah. Got a light? The busboy pulls out a pack of matches from the back of h ‘Old Gold’s' and lights Don's cigarette. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 2.

dialogues.speaker: DON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ah, an 'Old Gold' man. (inhaling) ‘Lucky Strike', here. There is an awkward silence. The busboy starts to walk aw

dialogues.speaker: DON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something? Why do you smoke 'Old Gold'? The busboy seems flustered and looks around nervously. Th burly white BARTENDER approaches.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: I'm sorry sir. Is Sam here bothering you? He can be a little chatty.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: No, we're actually having a conversation. Is that okay?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: (thinking) Can I get you another drink?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: (points to drink) Do this again. Old Fashioned, please. The bartender walks off.

dialogues.speaker: DON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, obviously you need to relax after working here all night.

dialogues.speaker: BUSBOY
dialogues.text: I guess. I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: What is it, low-tar? Low-nicotine? Those new filters? I mean, why "Old Gold"?

dialogues.speaker: BUSBOY
dialogues.text: They gave them to us in the service. A carton a week for free.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: So you're used to them. Is that it? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06

dialogues.speaker: BUSBOY
dialogues.text: Yeah, they're a habit.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: So I could never get you to smoke another kind? Let's say, my Luckies?

dialogues.speaker: BUSBOY
dialogues.text: I love my Old Gold.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Let's just say tomorrow a tobacco weevil comes and eats every last Old Gold on the planet.

dialogues.speaker: BUSBOY
dialogues.text: That's a sad story.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Yes, it's a tragedy. Would you just stop smoking?

dialogues.speaker: BUSBOY
dialogues.text: I'm pretty sure I'd find something. I love smoking.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: (writing as he speaks) "I love smoking". That's very good.

dialogues.speaker: BUSBOY
dialogues.text: My wife hates it. "The Reader's Digest" says it will kill you.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Yeah, I heard about that.

dialogues.speaker: BUSBOY
dialogues.text: (shrugs ) Ladies love their magazines.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Yes, they do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don, hat in hand, knocks on the door. 3 4 He waits a beat and checks his watch. It's midnight. The door opens to reveal MIDGE DANIELS, a sexy no nonsense woman about Don's age wrapped in a red kimono. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 4.

dialogues.speaker: MIDGE
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) You weren't worried about waking me, were you?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Am I interrupting anything?

dialogues.speaker: MIDGE
dialogues.text: No, only my work. She turns and Don follows her shapely form into the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The apartment has a huge glass view of Manhattan and is decorated in Swedish modern: chrome, teak, and white. In center of the room, under a large mobile, is a queen-size on a platform. Midge walks to her drafting table where she is working. D sits on the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MIDGE
dialogues.text: Well, you're lucky I'm still up working. And that I'm alone.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: MIDGE
dialogues.text: They invented something called "Grandmother's Day". It ought to keep me busy drawing puppies for a few months. She holds up a few of the greeting cards that she has bee working on.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Can I run a few ideas past you? Midge smiles and heads to the bar to fix a couple of drin

dialogues.speaker: MIDGE
dialogues.text: Does that mean what I think it means? Because I'm familiar with most of your ideas. Don starts leafing through his pockets, pulling out napki (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 5.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I have this situation with my cigarette account.

dialogues.speaker: MIDGE
dialogues.text: (surprised) Wow, you really are here to talk.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: The Trade Commission is cracking down on all of our health claims.

dialogues.speaker: MIDGE
dialogues.text: I get "Reader's Digest". (handing him a drink) This is the same scare you had five years ago. You dealt with it. I know I slept easier knowing that doctors smoke.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: But that's the problem. The whole "safer cigarette" thing is over. No more doctors, no more testimonials, no more cough-free, soothes your t-zone, low-tar, low- nicotine, filter-tipped, nothing. It's over. All that's left is a crush-proof box and "Four Out of Five Dead People Smoked Your Brand." Don drains his drink. Midge puts on a record. She sits behind him on the bed, starts rubbing his neck.

dialogues.speaker: MIDGE
dialogues.text: Is this the part where I say, "Don Draper is the greatest ad-man ever and his big strong brain will find a way to lead the sheep to the slaughterhouse"? Don grabs her hands over his shoulders, pulls her over an kisses her on the lips lightly.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I don't want to go to school tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: MIDGE
dialogues.text: Are you going to pitch it to me or not? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “Smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 6.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Midge, I'm serious. I have nothing. I'm over and they're finally going to know it. The next time you see me there'll be a bunch of young executives picking the meat off my ribs.

dialogues.speaker: MIDGE
dialogues.text: That's a pretty picture.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: What's your secret?

dialogues.speaker: MIDGE
dialogues.text: Nine different ways to say, "I love you, Grandma." She opens her kimono revealing she has nothing on underne and pulls Don's head to her chest. As she smiles with pleasure, we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don is laying on Midge's chest. Midge smokes a cigarette. Don looks off towards the skyline.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: We should get married.

dialogues.speaker: MIDGE
dialogues.text: You think I'd make a good ex-wife? Don sits up and grabs a cigarette off the end table.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I'm serious. You have your own business and you don't care when I come over. What size Cadillac do you take? Midge lays on the bed completely naked, staring at Don.

dialogues.speaker: MIDGE
dialogues.text: You know the rules. I don't make plans and I don't make breakfast. She smiles a little and throws Don his watch. He puts it (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 7.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Sterling is having the tobacco people in nine hours. I have nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MIDGE
dialogues.text: People love smoking. There's nothing that you, the Trade Commission, or "Reader's Digest" can do to change that.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: There's a kid who comes by my office everyday and looks where he's going to put his plants.

dialogues.speaker: MIDGE
dialogues.text: Is he handsome? EXT. TOWERING MANHATTAN SKYSCRAPER —- MORNING 8 From the air, we see an elegant modern glass building. Below, the hats on the tops of men's heads swarm like ant through revolving doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A middle-aged black man mans the controls of the crowded elevator. Three young execs, KEN, DICK, and HARRY, in apparently identical suits take off their hats and crowd the back of the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Twenty-three.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Oh, but not right away. An attractive YOUNG SECRETARY, holding her purse to her chest, steps on the elevator and turns her back to them. three men look her over and nod to each other approvingly

dialogues.speaker: KEN
dialogues.text: (to the operator) Pal, can you take the long way up? I’m really enjoying the view here. The secretary looks down. The operator says nothing. Dick slouches against the back wall. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 8.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: You going to Campbell's bachelor party?

dialogues.speaker: KEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I want to be there before they tie an anchor around his neck and drag him out to sea.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: I heard she's a nice girl.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Who wants that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow the threesome as they wind down the hall of the busy office. It's ultra-modern with teak panelling and Barcelona chairs.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: What did you do that for? She'll probably be assigned to one of us.

dialogues.speaker: KEN
dialogues.text: Then she'll know what she's in for. Besides, you have to let them know what kind of guy you are. Then they'll know what kind of girl to be.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: (to Ken) I have a feeling we won't be going to your bachelor party anytime soon.

dialogues.speaker: KEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, compared to Campbell, I'm a boy scout. They walk past an attractive secretary, HILDY, who stands as if to stop them.

dialogues.speaker: HILDY
dialogues.text: Excuse me, is he expecting you?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: He's not expecting anything. Ken holds his finger to his lips as the three men burst o the door to see --  11 Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 9. INT. PETE’S OFFICE - DAY 11 PETE CAMPBELL. He is mid-twenties, charming, all-American and on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: (to phone) Oh, honey, don't worry, I'll get home safely. I have an important appointment right now, so why don't you go shopping or something? Take your mother to lunch, tell her it was my idea.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: (to Ken) Wow, he's good. The three guys, Ken, Dick, and Harry, settle into differe places around the office. A few of them light cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: (to phone) It's just a bachelor party. ... No, I really don't know what they have planned, but judging from the creative brainpower around here, we'll probably end up seeing "My Fair Lady". Ken looks offended and takes a card out of his pocket wit drawing of a stripper, on it is written "The Slipper Room He holds it up for Pete.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (still on phone) I'll tell you what. I'11l stop by your place on my way home. Your mother can check under my fingernails. ... Of course I love you. I'm giving up my life to be with you, aren't I? He laughs and hangs up the phone and picks up her picture from his desk.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What a great gal. I'1l tell you guys, she stole my heart.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: And her old man's loaded. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 11 12 Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 10.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As Pete laughs, he grabs the card with the stripper from

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking down a wide corridor with open offices on either is JOAN, mid-twenties, an incredibly put together office manager. A half step behind her, carrying a cardboard box with supplies is PEGGY OLSON, who at 20 seems far younger

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Now this is the Executive floor. It should be organized but it's not, so you'll find Account Executives and Creative Executives, all mixed together. (laughing) Please don't ask me the difference.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Hopefully, if you follow my lead, you can avoid some of the mistakes I made here. Ken and Dick pass in the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: (as he passes) Hello, Joan.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: (to Peggy, re: Dick) Like that one. So, how many trains did it take you?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Only one, but I got up very early.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: In a couple of years, with the right moves, you'll be in the city with the rest of us. Of course, if you really make the right moves, you'll be out in the country and you won't be going to work at all. They push through a couple of double doors to another set offices with secretarial desks in front of them. Joan poi to an empty desk. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 11.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'll be there, just across the aisle from me. We'll both take care of Mr. Draper for the time being. Peggy sits down and starts unloading her things. Joan sta in front of her, very business-like.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don't know what your goals are, but don't over-do it with the perfume. Keep a fifth of something in your desk. Mr. Draper drinks rye. Also, invest in some aspirin, some band-aids, and a needle and thread. Peggy whips out a steno-pad and starts writing.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Rye is Canadian, right?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: You better find out. He may act like he wants a secretary, but most of the time they're looking for something between a mother and a waitress. The rest of the time, well -- (confidentially) Go home, take a paper bag, cut eyeholes out of it. Put it over your head, get undressed and look at yourself in the mirror. Really evaluate where your strengths and weaknesses are. And be honest. Peggy looks up at her, a little stunned.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: I always try to be honest.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Good for you. As Peggy places her gleaming stapler on the desk, she sta at the two button intercom, the rotary telephone, and the electric typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now try not to be overwhelmed by all this technology. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 12 13 Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 12.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It looks complicated, but the men who designed it made it simple enough for a woman to use.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: I sure hope so.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: At lunch, you need to pick up a box of chocolates, a dozen carnations, and some bath salts. I'1l explain later.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Miss Holloway. You're really wonderful for looking out for me this way.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: It’s Joan. Joan starts to head away, then turns back.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And listen, we're going to be working together so don't take this the wrong way, but a girl like you, with those darling little ankles, I'd find a way to make them sing. Also, men love scarves. Down the hallway comes a slightly disheveled Don Draper followed by ROGER STERLING, an elegant WASP with an incredible head of grey hair. Roger is the Sterling in "Sterling Cooper Advertising". As they whisk by, Joan straightens up and sticks her ches out. She motions for Peggy to stand up as well.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Draper. Oh! And Mr. Sterling! How are you?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Good morning, girls. As they enter Don's office, Don automatically hands Joan hat and overcoat and then closes the door behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger speaks as Don opens a cabinet and hangs up his coat (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13 Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 13.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: You look like a hundred bucks. Long night? It's not this tobacco thing, is it?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: It has been on my mind.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Well, I should hope so. Lee Garner and his father and the whole ‘Lucky Strike' family will be here at four.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Are you worried? Don opens a drawer revealing a stack of freshly identical white shirts still wrapped from the laundry. He takes one out and changes into it while they talk.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: No, if I was worried, I'd ask you what you have. But I'm not. So I'm just going to assume that you have something. Which means you should be worried. Don folds down his collar and starts tying his tie.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: So you came by because you wanted to watch me get dressed?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: No, I wanted make sure you were here. Don drops a couple of Alka-Seltzer into a glass.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: In body, yes. Give me about a half an hour for the rest. Roger heads out, but then stops, remembering something.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Do we have any...how do I put this? Have we ever hired any Jews?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Not on my watch. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13 14 Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 14.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Very funny. That's not what I meant.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: We've got an Italian. Salvatore, my art director?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: (disappointed) That won't work.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Sorry, but most of the Jewish guys work for Jewish firms.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: I know. Selling Jewish products to Jewish people.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: (pretending to write) That's good.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: It's just that our eleven o'clock is with Mencken’s Department Store and I wish we had somebody to make them feel comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: You want me to go down to the deli and grab somebody?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: (pointing to Don's shirt) You missed a button. Roger exits. Don buttons his shirt. He is now perfectly dressed. He looks out at the spectacular view of Manhatta and closes the venetian blinds. Now in his dim office, he lays carefully on the couch. He looks up at the ceiling a stares a moment at the dark florescent fixture. A fly buzzes, trapped inside. He closes his eyes. FADE OUT. INT. DON DRAPER’S OFFICE -- LATER 14

dialogues.speaker: OVER BLACK
dialogues.text: We hear Peggy's disembodied voice. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 14 Pilot Episode “Smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 15.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Draper? Excuse me? Mr. Draper? Fading up on Don’s POV Peggy stand over Don holding a glass of water in one hand

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Draper. Excuse me. I'm sorry to wake you, but Mr. Campbell is outside.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: He doesn't know I'm sleeping in here, does he?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: That's good. And who are you?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: I'm Peggy Olson. The new girl? Don looks at her, putting things together. He stands up a tucks in the tail of his shirt, runs a comb through his h

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Can you go out there and entertain him?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: I know it's my first day and I don't want to seem uncooperative, but... do I have to?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I see your point.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: (relieved) I brought you some aspirin. Don smiles and takes the glass and aspirin from her.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Send him in. As Peggy turns Pete swings the door open and enters. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 16.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You look like a hundred bucks. Ready to go sweet talk some retail Jews?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: You're hard to take first thing in the morning, Pete.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I've never had any complaints. Speaking of which, who's your little friend, here?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: She's the new girl.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You always get the new girl. Management gets all the perks. (to Peggy) Where are you from, honey?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Miss Deaver's Secretarial School.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Top notch. (he looks her over) But I meant where are you from? Are you Amish or something?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: No, I'm from Brooklyn.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Well you're in the city, now. It wouldn't be a sin for us to see your legs. And if you pull your belt in a little bit, you might look like a woman. Peggy tries to hide her embarrassment by ignoring Pete.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Is that all, Mr. Draper?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm not done here. I'm working my way up.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: (to Peggy) That'll be all-- it's Peggy, right? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 14 15 Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Draper. Oh, and it's time for your eleven o'clock meeting. Peggy starts to walk out.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: (to Peggy) Sorry about Mr. Campbell, here. He left his manners back at the fraternity house. Pete shrugs and holds open the door as Don exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don and Pete walk down the hallway together.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: She's a little young for you, Draper.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: The future Mrs. Pete Campbell is a lucky woman. When's the wedding, again?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Sunday. Did Ken tell you about the bachelor party tonight?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: He sure did.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: So do I get first crack at her? Word is she took down more sailors than the Arizona.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I just turned twenty-six.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I bet the world looks like one great big brassiere strap waiting to be snapped.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You are good with words, Draper. (CONTINUED )
14 15  15 16 Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 18.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Campbell, we're both men here, so I'll be direct.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Christ, are you already sleeping with her? Unfazed, Don continues as they round a corner.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Advertising is a very small world. And when you do something like malign the reputation of some girl from the steno pool on her first day, you make it even smaller. Keep it up and even if you do get my job, you'll never run this place. You'll die in that corner office: a mid-level account executive with a little bit of hair, who women go home with out of pity. They've arrived at the big board room. Don stops and whispers.

dialogues.speaker: DON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And you know why? Because no one will like you. Pete is speechless. Don smiles and opens the door. INT. STERLING COOPER BOARD ROOM — CONTINUOUS 16 Don enters, energized. Pete follows behind him, trying to smile. Inside, Roger waits with a few people, including RACHEL MENCKEN, early twenties and stunning in a Chanel s

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Well here are our miracle workers now. You already know Pete Campbell, of course, your Account Executive, if you choose to do business with us. And this handsome guy is Don Draper, the best Creative Director in New York.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Or at least the building. He holds his hand out to a young man. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 19.

dialogues.speaker: DON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You must be Mr. Mencken. Roger steps in.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: (to Don) Oh, I'm sorry about that.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (offering her hand) I'm Rachel Mencken.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I apologize. I was expecting, um--

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You were expecting me to be a man? My father was, too. Their eyes meet. After a beat, Don finally shakes her han

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: (to young man) And you are?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Why Don, you remember David Cohen from the Art Department.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: (covering) Oh, of course. David, one of the rising stars here at Sterling Cooper. David smiles awkwardly and wipes his hands on his pants.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: So why don't we all get comfortable and Miss Mencken, you tell us what you have in mind.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Wonderful. As they sit down, Don leans in to Roger.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: (sotto, re: David Cohen) Very subtle. Isn't that your shirt? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16 17 18 Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 20.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: I had to go all the way to the mail room, but I found one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old gothic building. Next to the revolving door we see plaque: "Midtown Medical Building".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy sits on the vinyl exam table reading a pamphlet, "I Your Wedding Night". Following a knock on the door, DR. EMERSON, early forties, enters with a clipboard under his arm.

dialogues.speaker: DR. EMERSON
dialogues.text: (reading chart) So, you must be Peggy Olson. Joan Holloway sent you over. She's a great girl. How is Joan?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: She sends her regards.

dialogues.speaker: DR. EMERSON
dialogues.text: She's a lot of fun. It must be a scream to work with her.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Yes. (thinking) It's pretty terrific.

dialogues.speaker: DR. EMERSON
dialogues.text: Try to make yourself comfortable and relax. Dr. Emerson nods towards the stirrups. Peggy leans back a stares up at the acoustic tile. Dr. Emerson adjusts the reflector on his forehead and begins to palpate Peggy's stomach.

dialogues.speaker: DR. EMERSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I see from your chart and your finger, you're not married.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: That's right. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 18 room. Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 21.

dialogues.speaker: DR. EMERSON
dialogues.text: And yet you're interested in the contraceptive pills?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Well, I--

dialogues.speaker: DR. EMERSON
dialogues.text: No reason to be nervous. Joan sent you to me because I'm not here to judge you. There's nothing wrong with a woman being practical about the possibility of sexual activity. Spread your knees.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: (trying to be casual) That's good to hear.

dialogues.speaker: DR. EMERSON
dialogues.text: Of course, as a doctor, one would like to think that putting a woman in this situation, it's not going to turn her into some kind of strumpet. Slide your fanny towards me. I'm not going to bite. Peggy winces as he inserts the speculum.

dialogues.speaker: DR. EMERSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll warn you now, I will take you off this medicine if you abuse it. Peggy looks towards him but is blinded by the light on hi forehead. All she hears is his disembodied voice.

dialogues.speaker: DR. EMERSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's really for your own good, but the fact is, even in our modern times, easy women don't find husbands.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: I understand, Dr. Emerson. I really am a very responsible person. He turns off his light and goes to the other side of the He lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: DR. EMERSON
dialogues.text: I'm sure you're not that kind of girl. Now, Joan... (he laughs) (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 18 19 Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 22.

dialogues.speaker: DR. EMERSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm kidding along here. You can get dressed. Peggy starts to awkwardly put her clothes on, turning her back to the Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: DR. EMERSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm going to write you a prescription for Enovid. They're eleven dollars a month. But don't think you have to go out and become the town pump to get your money's worth. Excuse my French. Peggy smiles politely and takes the prescription.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel Mencken sits between David Cohen and Pete listenin Don and Roger give their pitch-- Don standing by some moc ads. The table is lined with Shrimp Cocktails, toast points, and a pitcher of Bloody Mary's.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: So what Don's saying is that through a variety of media, including a spot during "The Danny Thomas Show" if you can afford it, we can really boost awareness.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Then, a ten-percent off coupon in select ladies' magazines will help increase your first time visitors. (sits, grabs a shrimp) After we've got them in the store, it's kind of up to you.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Mr. Draper, our store is sixty years old. We share a wall with Tiffany's. Honestly, a coupon?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Miss Mencken, coupons work. I think your father would agree with the strategy.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: He might. But he's not here because we just had our lowest sales year. Ever. So, I suppose what I think matters most right now. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 23.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rachel takes out a cigarette. Pete lights it, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Miss Mencken, why did you come here? There are a dozen other agencies better suited to your... needs.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: If I wanted some man who happened to be from the same village as my father to handle my account, I could have stayed where I was. Their research favors coupons, too.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Miss Mencken, it's not just research. Housewives love coupons.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I'm not interested in housewives.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: (frustrated) So, what kind of people do you want?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I want your kind of people, Mr. Draper. People who don't care about coupons, whether they can afford it or not. People who are coming to the store because it is expensive.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: We obviously have very different ideas.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yes, like "the customer is always right?" Gentlemen, I really thought you could do better than this. Sterling Cooper has a reputation for being innovative.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: (raising his voice) You are way out of line, Miss. Roger takes hold of the situation. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 24.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Don, please. Let's not get emotional, here. There's no reason we can't talk this out.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Talk out what? Some silly idea that people will go to some store they've never been to because it's more expensive.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: It works for "Chanel".

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: (steely) "Mencken’s" is not "Chanel".

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: That's a vote of confidence. Now Pete tries to ease the tension.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: What Don's saying is that "Chanel" is a very different kind of place. It's French. It's continental. It's--

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Not just another Jewish department store?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Exactly. Rachel stumps out her cigarette in the shrimp cocktail.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You were right Roger, this place really runs on charm.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: (standing up) This is ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Don--

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: (to Rachel) I'm not going to let a woman talk to me like this. This meeting is over. Good luck, Miss Mencken. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 19 20 Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 25.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Don storms out. Pete follows after him. David reaches for the pitcher of Bloody Mary's. As Roger glares, David awkwardly stops, caught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don walks down the corridor at a brisk clip with Pete trailing a step behind.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Hey, Don. I don't blame you. She was way out of line. (catching up) Adding money and education doesn't take the rude edge out of people.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Well, Roger's not going to be happy. So, I guess that's good for you. Pete grabs his arm, stops him.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I'm not going to pretend that I don't want your job. But you were right. I'm not great with people, and you are. I mean, not counting that meeting we were just in. So, I'm kind of counting on you to help me out. There's plenty of room at the top. Don calms down.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm sorry I was so hard on you before. It's this damn tobacco thing.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You'll think of something. A man like you I'd follow into combat blindfolded. And I wouldn’t be the first. Am I right, buddy? Pete holds out his hand. Don just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Let's take this a little slower. I don't want to wake up pregnant. As Don walks away, Pete tries not to look insulted. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20 21 22 Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 26.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan leads Peggy down the hallway. Peggy is holding the flowers, candy, and bath salts that were requested.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Dr. Emerson is a dream, isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: He seemed nice.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: He has a place in South Hampton. I'm not saying I've seen it, but it's beautiful. Joan stops in front of a door.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, don't be nervous, but this is the nerve center of this office. You and your boss depend on the willing and cheerful co-operation of a few skilled employees. Never snap, yell, or be sarcastic with them. And above all, always be a supplicant. Joan opens the door. The door to,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three women with headsets plug and unplug into a wall of wires, lights, and holes. There is a drone of ad-libbing, "Good afternoon. Sterling Cooper. Please hold. Mr. Dawson's office, please hold." Etc.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I know you girls are busy, but we've got a new one. Peggy, this is Marge, Nanette, and Ivy. They nod to Peggy while they work. Joan elbows Peggy.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: I brought you some things. I guess a sort of "getting to know you" gift. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22 Pilot Episode “Smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 27.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The women stop working. The board buzzes and lights conti as they chat.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: (to Peggy) Aren't you a sweetheart? If I know Joan, the candy's for me. Ivy You're not fair, Joan. You know she has to lose eight pounds by the Christmas party.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: I think you look great. Joan smiles, pleased that Peggy has picked up the cue.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: It's because I'm sitting down.

dialogues.speaker: NANETTE
dialogues.text: Come back and visit anytime, honey. (to Joan) Who does she work for?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Don Draper.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: They got rid of Eleanor?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: She moved on. Draper wasn't interested.

dialogues.speaker: NANETTE
dialogues.text: Well, she couldn't get a call through. Rude little thing.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I see you all have your hands full. We don't want to be a bother.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Nice meeting you. They go back to work answering the phones. Ivy (to Peggy) You have great legs. I bet Mr. Draper would like them if he could see them. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22 23 Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 28.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She smiles at Peggy as Joan pulls her toward the door. INT. DON DRAPER'S OFFICE —- AFTERNOON 23 Don leans back in his chair eyes closed for a moment then slaps his face to alert himself. He opens a desk drawer, pulling out a chest exerciser which is just a few springs some handles. As he does a small black leather box drops the floor, popping open. He puts the exerciser on the des and returns the contents to the box-- we see it’s a US AR purple heart medal. He flips the lid closed, “LIEUT. DONA FRANCIS DRAPER” in gold on the outside. He regards it a moment and puts it back in the drawer. He then taps a cigarette out, lights it and begins to exercise as he smo SALVATORE ROMANO, transparently gay--although in 1960, no seems to know it--stands in the doorway with a hand on hi hip like Marlene Dietrich.

dialogues.speaker: SALVATORE
dialogues.text: Aw look at you, Gidget. Still trying to fill out that bikini?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: It's worth a try. Salvatore puts a couple of trace paper sketches on the de

dialogues.speaker: SALVATORE
dialogues.text: Without the medical claims all we have is a white box with a red spot on it. He shows Don a sketch of a shirtless man in a hammock smoking. The word above says, "Relax..."

dialogues.speaker: SALVATORE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My neighbor posed for this. Believe me, he always looks very relaxed. (giggles a little) Of course, he doesn't smoke. I had him hold a pencil.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: If I know these guys, you're better off with a little sex appeal. Can you give me a woman in a bathing suit? Put your guy next to her?

dialogues.speaker: SALVATORE
dialogues.text: Oh, a sexy girl? I can do that. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 29.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Give you a chance to get a real model.

dialogues.speaker: SALVATORE
dialogues.text: (too enthusiastic) I love my work! Speaking of sexy girls, are you going to Pete's bachelor party?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I'm not really big on those things.

dialogues.speaker: SALVATORE
dialogues.text: Oh, tell me about it. It's so embarrassing. If a girl's going to shake it in my face, I want to be alone so I can do something. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salvatore opens the desk drawer and takes out a bottle of whiskey and two glasses. *

dialogues.speaker: SALVATORE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Should we drink before the meeting or after? Or both? *

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: So that's it, huh? "Relax...", that's all we have?

dialogues.speaker: SALVATORE
dialogues.text: Don't be short with me. You're the writer. I thought it was worth a try. The intercom buzzes. Don hits the button.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Greta Guttman is here to see you.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Send her in. Sal drops a couple of Alka-Seltzer into a glass of whiske

dialogues.speaker: SALVATORE
dialogues.text: Great. Now we have to hear from our man in research. Peggy opens the door and shows GRETA GUTTMAN, a fifty-ish German national who embodies the sober world of research right down to her bun hairstyle and clipboard. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: Mr. Draper. Mr. Romano. Her eyes follow Peggy as she leaves.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I see you have another attractive young plaything.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: You can fight with Campbell over her. 30. 23 Salvatore spits his drink back into his glass, stifling a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: (amused) You both seem more relaxed than I expected. Do you have some kind of surprise for the tobacco people?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: (re: cigarette) I'm doing my own research.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: If you are planning to continue with medical testimony, you'll only be inviting further government interference. We must police ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: SALVATORE
dialogues.text: Well there's your slogan.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: (to Greta) The medical thing is dead, we all understand that.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: Yes, dead. An apt choice of words. Considering the public is convinced that cigarettes are poisonous. If we can't insist that they're not, I believe my most recent surveys have provided a solution. (xe report) We can still suggest that cigarettes are "part of American life," or “Too good to give up,” and most appealing "an assertion of independence". (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 31.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: So basically if you love danger, you'll love smoking?

dialogues.speaker: SALVATORE
dialogues.text: We could put a skull and crossbones on the label! I love it!

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: Before the war, when I studied with * Adler in Vienna, we postulated that * what Freud called "the Death Wish" is as powerful a drive as those for sexual reproduction and physical sustenance.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Freud, you say-- which agency is he * with? *

dialogues.speaker: SALVATORE
dialogues.text: So we're supposed to believe people are living one way and secretly thinking the exact opposite? That's ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Let me tell you something, Miss Guttman-—

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Dr. Guttman, psychology is terrific * at a cocktail party, but it happens * people were buying cigarettes before Freud was born. The issue isn't, "why should people smoke"-- it's why should people smoke "Lucky Strike". Suggesting our customers have a, what did you call it? A "Death Wish"? Well, I just don't see that on a billboard.

dialogues.speaker: SALVATORE
dialogues.text: It's all a big scare anyway. So what if "Reader's Digest" says they're dangerous? They also said "Bambi" was the book of the century. There's no proof, no studies. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 32. 23 Greta exits.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: There's conclusive proof that none of these low-tar, low-nicotine or filtration systems have any effect on the incidences of lung cancer.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: This isn't Germany. If you were right, the government would shut down the tobacco companies, not just limit advertising. Just give me the damn report.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: (hands it to him) I think you'll find it very convincing.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I'm sure I will. You were the one who dug up all our medical testimonials to begin with.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: That's true, Mr. Draper, but-- Greta gives what passes for a smile.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Has anyone else seen this?

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: No, of course not. It's your account.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Good. I don't want to hear about it again. I'm sorry, but I find your whole approach perverse.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: I understand. Good luck at the meeting. (on exit) I'm sure it will be a quick one.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Sal, I'll take that drink now. Don throws the report into the wastebasket. FADE OUT.  24 25 Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 33.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: INT. STERLING COOPER BOARD ROOM —- AFTERNOON 25 The large table in the board room is covered with ashtray LEE GARNER JUNIOR, a forty-ish tobacco magnate, and his father, LEE GARNER SENIOR, sit flanked with other tobacco executives. Across the table, Roger, Don, and Pete listen patiently to LEE GARNER Sr.'s lilting southern anger.

dialogues.speaker: LEE GARNER SENIOR
dialogues.text: I just don't know what we have to do to make these government interlopers happy. They tell us to build a safer cigarette, and we do it. Then suddenly, that's not good enough.

dialogues.speaker: LEE GARNER JUNIOR
dialogues.text: We might as well be living in Russia. He coughs. Suddenly, a round of spontaneous coughing begi among all of the people in the board room. It dies down.

dialogues.speaker: LEE GARNER SENIOR
dialogues.text: Damn straight. You know this morning, I got a call from my competitors at Brown & Williamson, and they're getting sued by the federal government because of the health claims they made.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: We're aware of that, Mr. Garner. But you have to realize that through manipulation of the mass media, the public is under the impression that your cigarettes are linked to... certain fatal diseases.

dialogues.speaker: LEE GARNER SENIOR
dialogues.text: Manipulation of the media? That's what I hired you for. Our product is fine. I smoke them myself.

dialogues.speaker: LEE GARNER JUNIOR
dialogues.text: My Granddad smoked them. He died at 95 years old. He was hit by a truck. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 34.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: I understand, but our hands are tied. We are no longer allowed to advertise that "Lucky Strikes" are safe.

dialogues.speaker: LEE GARNER SENIOR
dialogues.text: So what the hell are we going to do? We already funded our own tobacco research center to put this whole rumor to rest.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: And that's a great start. But it may not affect sales. Don, I think that's your cue. Don opens up a folder, it's filled with blank pages. He pretends to shuffle the pages around, stalling.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Well, I... I've really thought about this. And hell, you know I'm a "Lucky Strike" man from way back... From Don's POV, we see the anxious stares of all those at table. In slow motion, cigarettes are being lit and men a exhaling. A bead of sweat forms on Don's brow. His heart pounding in his ears. Suddenly, the silence is broken by Pete's voice.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I might have a solution. Don does not seem relieved as Pete takes the stage. Roger catches Don's eye, but Don looks away.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: At Sterling Cooper, we've been pioneering the burgeoning the field of research. And our analysis shows that the health risks associated with your products is not the end of the world. As the executives look at each other curiously, Don sees is reading from Greta's report.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: People get in their cars everyday to go to work, and some of them die. Cars are dangerous. There's nothing you can do about it. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “Smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 35.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You still have to get where you're going. Cigarettes are exactly the same. Why don't we simply say, "So what if cigarettes are dangerous?" You're a man. The world is dangerous. Smoke your cigarette-- You still have to get where you're going.

dialogues.speaker: LEE GARNER JUNIOR
dialogues.text: That's very interesting. (then) I mean, if cigarettes were dangerous, that would be interesting. Roger looks around nervously to see if they're going to b

dialogues.speaker: LEE GARNER SENIOR
dialogues.text: Except they aren't. Is that your slogan? "You're going to die anyway. Die with us."?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Actually, it's a fairly well established psychological principal that society has a "Death Wish". And if we could tap into that, the market potential--

dialogues.speaker: LEE GARNER SENIOR
dialogues.text: What the hell are you talking about? Why not just write "cancer" on the package? Are you insane? I'm not selling rifles. I'm in the tobacco business-- I'm selling America. The Indians gave it to us for shit's sake.

dialogues.speaker: LEE GARNER JUNIOR
dialogues.text: Come on, Dad. Let's get out of here. They stand up.

dialogues.speaker: LEE GARNER JUNIOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (he helps his father up) The bright spot is, at least we know that if we have this problem, everybody has this problem. Don's ears perk up at this last comment. He lets it sink (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 36.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, before you leave, can I say something?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: (pointed) I don't know. Can you, Don?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: The Federal Trade Commission and "Reader's Digest" have done you a favor. They've let you know that any ad that brings up the concept of health and cigarettes together, well, it just makes people think of cancer.

dialogues.speaker: LEE GARNER SENIOR
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Yes, and we're grateful to them.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: But, what Lee Junior said is right. If you can't make health claims, neither can your competitors.

dialogues.speaker: LEE GARNER SENIOR
dialogues.text: Great, so we got a lot of people not saying anything that sells cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Not exactly. This is the greatest advertising opportunity since the invention of cereal. We have six identical companies with six identical products... We can say anything we want. The men sit down, interested. Don walks over to a black board.

dialogues.speaker: DON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How do you make your cigarettes?

dialogues.speaker: LEE GARNER JUNIOR
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: LEE GARNER SENIOR
dialogues.text: (to his son) Shame on you. (to Don) (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 25 Pilot Episode “Smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06

dialogues.speaker: LEE GARNER SENIOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We breed insect-resistant tobacco seeds, plant ‘em in the North Carolina sunshine, grow it, cut it, cure it, toast it, treat it--

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: There you go. Don writes on the board: "Lucky Strike - It's 'Toasted'. The men all look at it, not sure how to react.

dialogues.speaker: LEE GARNER JUNIOR
dialogues.text: But everybody else's tobacco is toasted.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: No. Everybody else's tobacco is poisonous. "Lucky Strike" is toasted. Roger's face lights with a slow smile of pride and awe.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I don't have to tell you what you've just witnessed here.

dialogues.speaker: LEE GARNER JUNIOR
dialogues.text: I think you do. Don gathers his thoughts and lowers his voice.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Advertising is based on one thing: happiness. And you know what happiness is? 37. 25
Don looks out the window into the setting sun, almost los

dialogues.speaker: DON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Happiness is the smell of a new car... It's freedom from fear. It's a billboard on the side of the road that screams with reassurance that whatever you're doing is okay. (almost to himself) You are okay. The tobacco people look at each other with understanding relief.

dialogues.speaker: LEE GARNER SENIOR
dialogues.text: (quietly impressed) "It's 'Toasted'." I get it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 25 26 Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 38.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Don underlines the slogan with the chalk. As he turns and looks over at Pete's disappointed face, he smiles and tap out a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger stands at the bar, fixing drinks. Don sits at his d with his feet up, smoking a cigar.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: You had me worried. I don't know if you were drunk or not drunk, but that was inspired. He hands Don a drink. As he does, Don notices that Greta' report is no longer in the waste basket.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: For the record, I pulled it out of thin air. (he looks up) Thank you, up there.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: You're looking the wrong way. (Don laughs) So, while I’ve got you in the afterglow here, what do you say you reconsider this presidential campaign?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I don’t know, bunting and babies, that’s hard work-- I’d just make a hash of it.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Modesty, that’s adorable. I expect significant billings on this thing. Country houses for all of us. And if that doesn’t make you patriotic, think about the product: he’s young, handsome, beautiful wife, Navy Hero, honestly Don, it shouldn’t be hard to convince America Dick Nixon is a winner. The intercom buzzes.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Draper? You have visitors. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “Smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 38A

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Honey, could you be a little more specific? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 39.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ken, Dick, and Harry bust through the door with Pete in t

dialogues.speaker: KEN
dialogues.text: We heard you saved the day. He slams down a bottle of "Canadian Club". Don looks at i

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Thanks, boys. I appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: (sucking up) I told them how amazing you were. I'm still tingling. The guys start fixing themselves drinks.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Well it looks like you're all about to engage in a little mid-level camaraderie, so I'll be on my way. And Don, thanks for the home run.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I love to come through.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: (quietly) Speaking of that, any way you can patch things up with Rachel Mencken? Any chance you could be as charming as I said you were?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Haven't you had enough of my magic for one day?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: She's worth two million dollars.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: You're a whore. Roger salutes and exits. Don hits the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Can she get us some more ice?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Draper?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: (to intercom) Just a minute. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 26 Pilot Episode “Smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06

dialogues.speaker: DON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (then to them) I think this party needs to move elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: We'll move wherever you want, but it's five fifteen, the bachelor party's underway.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I don't know--

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Aw, come on, Don. All hands on deck.

dialogues.speaker: KEN
dialogues.text: Aren't you going to help us give Pete his big send-off?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: (pointed to Pete) Maybe some other time.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Come on, guys. He puts down a card of the strip club.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don will join us later, right Don? 40. 26 Pete holds open the door as the guys file out. Don looks Pete in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: If Greta's research was any good, I would have used it.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I'm saying I had a report just like that, and it's not like there's some magic machine that makes identical copies of things.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I still think she's right. Peggy stands in the doorway. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 26 Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 41.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Have a great night, Pete. Congratulations. He shakes Pete's hand. Pete simmers and walks away. Don goes back to his desk and looks through his notes. Peggy stands next to him.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: I heard you were amazing in the meeting.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Fear really stimulates my imagination.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: I just wanted to thank you for a great first day. And for, you know, standing up for me with Mr. Campbell. She puts her hand on top of his.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: First of all, Peggy, I'm your boss, not your boyfriend. (removing her hand) And second of all, you let Pete Campbell go through my trash again, and you won't be able to get a job selling sandwiches at Penn Station.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: (eyes welling) He said he left his fountain pen in here, I didn't know... I hope you don't think I'm the kind of girl--

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Of course not... Now go home, put your curlers in, and let's start fresh again tomorrow. Peggy starts to head out.

dialogues.speaker: DON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, and Peggy, I need you to place a call.  27 Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Live jazz sizzles in the background. A buxom blonde STRIP is onstage. She unzips her dress in the back and slowly shakes it to the floor. Through the smoke-filled air we see Ken, Dick, Harry, Salvatore, and Pete sitting at a corner booth. They are drinking and laughing, but Pete is in no mood to particip Ken hands a scantily clad WAITRESS ten dollars.

dialogues.speaker: KEN
dialogues.text: (to waitress) I want to see you here every fifteen minutes, whether you have drinks or not. As she puts the drinks down, she shows them her cleavage.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Every five minutes. The waitress smiles and crosses off. They all watch her.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Let's live here.

dialogues.speaker: SALVATORE
dialogues.text: (to Pete) You better do more than look, tonight.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You have a girlfriend, Salvatore?

dialogues.speaker: SALVATORE
dialogues.text: (proud) Come on, I'm Italian. Just then, three beautiful young women in cocktail dresse and pearls approach the table. WANDA, a brunette with too much hairspray, sits down next to Pete.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: Is there some kind of party here? Pete turns to Ken.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You shouldn't have. Pete turns to Ken as the women chat with Salvatore. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 43.

dialogues.speaker: KEN
dialogues.text: Hey, how many times are you going to get married?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: (looking them over) How did you swing it?

dialogues.speaker: KEN
dialogues.text: They work at the Automat.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: (laughing) He pressed a button, and they came out. The girls squeeze into the booth. CLEO, a red-head with f eyelashes, puts her arm around Salvatore and holds a cigarette to her lips. Salvatore lights it.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: I hope we're not interrupting anything.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Definitely not. CAMILLE, a platinum blonde in a Chinese dress squeezes in between Ken and Harry.

dialogues.speaker: CAMILLE
dialogues.text: Well I have the best seat. What are we drinking?

dialogues.speaker: KEN
dialogues.text: More of whatever's making you the way you are.

dialogues.speaker: CLEO
dialogues.text: (to Salvatore) I love this place. It's hot, loud, and filled with men.

dialogues.speaker: SALVATORE
dialogues.text: (looking around) I know what you mean. Cleo looks at Salvatore curiously. Wanda leans over and grabs Pete's hand with the drink in and pulls it to her lips. She takes a sip, then reacts li a little girl. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 44.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: (giggling) Oh my god, I can already feel it.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I have a feeling you're like this all the time.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: I like to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: (leaning in to her) Is that right? We see his hand reach under the table to her knee. He tickles her a little. She squirms and giggles.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: (playful) Now, you stop that.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You said you like to laugh. He tickles her again. She throws her head back, laughing louder.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: (warning) I mean it. It's too--

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Too delicious? We see his hand slide up under her dress. A look of shock goes over Wanda's face. She stops laughing and instinctiv brusquely pushes him away.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: Hey! I said stop it. What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You know exactly. Wanda stands and picks up her purse.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: You know what girls, I think we should go.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Oh, come on. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “Smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 45.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Pete grabs her arm. She tries to move.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: (under her breath) You're hurting me.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: (letting go) I'll be good. Wanda rubs her arm and sits down on the other side of the table. The waitress comes over. Pete throws some money.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get the girls whatever they want. Wanda stares at Pete and then links arms with Dick.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: (to Dick) So what do you fellows do?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: You're looking at the finest ad-men in New York. Hell, the world. As Wanda throws her head back laughing, we see Pete sulle staring off at the stripper. Her bra explodes off of her, revealing two sequined pasties on her gigantic breasts. A the applause begins, the spot light blacks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A white-coated OLD WAITER weaves through the more formal, lounge room of the bar, as well-dressed couples have inti drinks by candlelight. He arrives at a booth where Don an Rachel sit across from each other.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WAITER
dialogues.text: For the lady, a special mai-tai. He puts down a large fruit and umbrella covered glass.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WAITER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And one whiskey, neat. Rachel takes a sip through a long straw. She is stunning, her diamond earrings sparkling in the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: So you're going to ply me with drinks and convince me what a terrible mistake I'm making? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 46.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: That is quite a drink.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You got in trouble, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I shouldn't have lost my temper, and I certainly shouldn't have treated you like anything less than a client.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Apology accepted. Don smiles and offers her a cigarette. She takes one.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: So you understand.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Now I do. It was refreshing really, I mean, actually hearing all the things I always assumed people were thinking.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I'm really not as bad as all that. I was under a lot of pressure. Another account. It doesn't really matter.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: No, it doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: So without making things worse, can I ask you a personal question?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Don't you want to get a second drink in me first?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Why aren't you married?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Are you asking what's wrong with me?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: It's just you're a beautiful, educated woman. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “Smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 47.

dialogues.speaker: DON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't you think getting married and having a family would make you a lot happier than all the headaches that go with fighting people like me?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: If I weren't a woman, I would be allowed to ask you the same question. And I suppose if I weren't a woman I wouldn't have to choose between putting on an apron and the thrill of making my father's store what I always thought it should be.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: So that's it? You won't get married because you think business is a thrill?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (smiling) That, and I have never been in love.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: "She won't get married because she's never been in love." I think I wrote that. It was to sell nylons.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: For a lot of people, love isn't just a slogan.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Oh, "love". You mean the big lightning bolt to the heart, where you can't eat, can't work, so you run off and get married and make babies. He looks at Rachel and smiles. She doesn't smile back.

dialogues.speaker: DON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The reason you haven't felt it is because it doesn't exist. What you call "love" was invented by guys like me to sell nylons.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Is that right? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 48.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I'm pretty sure about it. You're born alone, you die alone, and this world just drops a bunch of rules on top of you to make you forget those facts. But I never forget. (finishing drink) I'm living like there's no tomorrow, because there isn't one. Rachel just stares at him with a long, forgiving look.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I don't think I realized it until this moment, but it must be hard being a man, too.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Mr. Draper-- He corrects her.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Don.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Mr. Draper, I don't know what it is you really believe in, but I know what it feels like to be out of place. To be disconnected. To see the world laid out in front of you the way other people live it. And there is something about you that tells me you know it too. Don nervously reaches for another cigarette and lights it

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I don't know if that's true. (then) You want another drink?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: No. But you can tell your boss that you charmed me. She stands up and turns her back to Don. He helps her on with her coat. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 28 29 Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 49.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: So I guess we'll be seeing each other again.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I'll be back in the office Monday morning for a real meeting. She turns to face him. They are very close. Don looks at her. She is luminous.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I'd like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete in his top coat stands in front of an apartment door leaning his head against the wall. He is obviously drunk knocks on the door. A young woman, MARJORIE, in a pink housecoat opens the do holding a toothbrush.

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: We're not buying anything.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Actually, for the first time today, I'm not selling anything. Does Peggy live here?

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: Do you know that it's nine-thirty?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: (re: watch) Actually it's nine-fifteen. Is Peggy in?

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: Hold on. She closes the door. She opens it again. Peggy comes to t door in a white bathrobe and slippers.

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you know him?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: It's okay, Marjorie. We work together. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot Episode “Smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 50.

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE
dialogues.text: (under her breath) He's really drunk.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: It's okay, Marjorie. Marjorie gives a stare and walks back. Peggy closes the d behind her and stands in the hallway with Pete.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: So what are you up to? Peggy smiles.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Nothing. Sitting in my room listening to records. Getting ready for bed. Another big day tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I'm getting married on Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: I heard that.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You must think I'm a creep.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: (firmly) Why are you here? Pete looks down and takes a step toward her. He leans in very close to her. His lips are almost on her forehead. H talks over her head.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I wanted to see you tonight.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: (without moving) Me?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: (whispers) I had to see you. Peggy's hand turns the door knob. She opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Marjorie? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 30 31 32 33 34 Pilot Episode “smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 51.

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah, Peg?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: I'm going to bed now. Peggy takes Pete's hand and leads him into the apartment. The door closes and fills the frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The silver blur of train cars passes. We follow up a wind where Don sits nursing a drink, reading the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don and a few other trench coated hat wearing businessmen exit the station and run in the light drizzle to the park lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls in. Door opens, Don heads to the front door He fumbles with his keys and puts them into the brightly painted red door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the dimly lit entryway, Don shakes off the rain and cl the stairs to a bedroom door. INT. DON AND BETTY’S BEDROOM 34 Suddenly we are close on a woman's hand as it turns the switch on the end table lamp. We pull back and reveal BET 29, and beautiful despite having just awakened.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I called the office and they'd said you'd left. Don comes over and gives her a kiss on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I didn't want to bother you. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34 35 36 Pilot Episode “Smoke Gets in Your Eyes” Pink 4/20/06 52.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: It's no bother, I just assumed you were staying in the city again. There's a plate in the oven. She helps him take off his tie and opens his shirt. He smiles at her and gives her a deep kiss.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (smiling) Unless you're not hungry--

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I'm not. (standing) I'll be right back. Don't move. INT. DRAPER’S CHILDREN’S BEDROOM — CONTINUOUS 35 We watch Don's feet, now in slippers, cross the floor. He eases onto the side of the bed. His hand reaches out to gently stroke a shock of gold hair. We pull out to reveal is sitting between the twin beds containing Robert and Sa his two children. Don has a hand on each of their heads as they sleep. He looks up to the doorway where Betty now leans in her peignoir, smiling at the scene of domestic bliss. Don loo away to the window. We follow his gaze as we,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pull back from the dimly lit window. The rain has stopped. Another car pulls in next door. A man gets out a heads in. Houses stretch in the distance. FADE OUT.
